NewWords.WordPhrase: in the center of 在…中心
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Apartments in the heart of the city are too expensive.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 厄瓜多尔人   a. 厄瓜多尔的
a. not changed or damaged yet 未改变的，未受破坏的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Local people told us that this was the only unspoiled forest in this country.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  a feeling of respect and liking for sb./sth. 钦佩，羡慕
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We have a great admiration for the people's heroes.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. far away from cities and difficult to reach 偏僻的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Their destination this time is a quiet, out-of-the-way resort.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 树桩
n. the slope of a bank especially of a stream （尤指溪流的）岸坡
n.  盖屋顶的材料；茅草屋顶
n. the place where a river begins 源头
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Do you know where is the headwaters of the Yangtze River?

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 欧夜鹰
vi.  be or become silent 安静下来，变得安静
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Having cried for half an hour, the little boy hushed.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. in an idle manner 空闲地，懒惰地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Since we've got a long holiday we spend a lot of time watching TV, drinking, shopping, or just stay at home idly.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  鸟蛛，狼蛛
n. 蛾，蛀虫
n.  电灯泡；球状物
n. 萤火虫
vt. scatter (drops of liquid, etc.) on a surface 溅，洒
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Hot grease spattered in all directions.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. shine light on 照亮，照明
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The sky was illumined by flashes from the volcano.

NewWords.WordPhrase: at one time...at another time... 忽而…忽而…
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The junior officer who came into the room looked nervous; his eyes swiveled quickly, now this way, now that, as if he were scanning the room for danger.

NewWords.WordPhrase: with (complete) absence of sound or noise （完全）不出声地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The kids were listening to the music in the classroom, in complete silence.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. catch in or as in a net, trap; mix together or intertwine in a confused mass 使卷入，使陷入；使缠结，使混乱
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I have the sort of hair that tangles easily.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  泡沫，水沫
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We see foam on water with a lot of soap in it.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi.  extend over a surface 蔓延，伸展
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Roses trailing over the walls made her garden so beautiful.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. form or bend into a loop 使成环状
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She looped the scarf round her neck and went out into the cold night air.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v.  wind; twist 蜿蜒；缠绕，交织
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The fence post was twined by vines.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. reduce or stop the sound of 减弱（或停止）…的声音
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. At the sight of their teacher walking into the classroom, they muted their voices.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. fade away, disappear 消散，消失
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The characteristics of gases vary widely. Some gases are transparent, some dissolve in water, and some have a strong smell.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad.  向下游；在下游
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We drifted downstream.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. untie, release 解开，放开
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The hunter loosed the arrow without warning.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  a length of woven hair, rope, etc. 辫子；辫状编织物
vi. leave a ship or airplane after a voyage 上岸，登陆
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I looked towards the plane. Six passenger had already disembarked.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. sit or fall down heavily 重重地坐下（或倒下）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Kennedy had been hit and slumped to the floor of the automobile.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 西班牙语
n.  盖丘亚族（南美印第安人分支）语；盖丘亚族人
n. （脚）趾

NewWords.Word: be dying to do sth. /for sth.
NewWords.WordPhrase: desire (to do) sth. eagerly 非常想做某事（或得到某物）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She was dying to tell them the good news that she had won first prize in the speech contest.

NewWords.WordPhrase: catch hold of, find or get (sth.) 抓到，得到
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I wish I could get my hands on a copy of Harry Potter.

NewWords.WordPhrase: separate into its different parts 拆开，分开
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. When I was young, my parents never blamed me for taking my toys apart.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 牛仔裤
n. 排球
a.  extraordinary; very attractive or impressive 与众不同的；引人入胜的，壮观的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The British Museum, one of the most spectacular museums in the world, is renowned for its extensive and diverse collection.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the outer edge or limit of sth. 边缘，边界
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Near the outer fringes of the solar system lies dark blue Neptune, a gas giant that probably has no true surface.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a space sunk into something 洞穴
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The explorer fell into a muddy hollow while walking in the forest.

NewWords.WordPhrase: with specifics 详细地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The police asked the victim of the robbery to describe what happened to him in detail.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  a stream that flows into a larger stream or other body of water 支流
n., a.  河边（的），河畔（的）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His father used to live in the riverside cottage in Wales.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 番石榴
n. not clear enough to allow light through 不透光的，不透明的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Milk is often stored in opaque containers to prevent vitamins from being destroyed by light.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt.  make (sth.) dirty；spread (a thick liquid, etc.) over a surface 弄脏；涂抹
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Don't smear the glasses; I've just polished them.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  鹦鹉
n.  a group of certain animals （动物）群   in flocks a.  in groups 成群地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Penguins are gregarious birds and are found in flocks even at sea.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi.  move suddenly and rapidly 迅疾地飞（奔）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The boy darted behind the sofa as his father stormed into the living room.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 大水蟒
vt.  believe, consider 认为，称为
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She is widely reputed to be 25 years younger than her husband.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 大蟒蛇
n. 鳄鱼
vt. expose, uncover 使露出，裸露
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The dog bared its teeth.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a long narrow region of land or body of water; a long narrow piece 狭长的地域(或水域)；条，带
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. About 30 million people live along the Californian coastal strip.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 沙洲
ad. recently, newly 刚才，新近地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. This is Richard, who joined our team freshly.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v.  用桨划（船）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Canoes can be paddled by one or more persons.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (also dugout canoe) 独木舟
n. 吊床
n. one that explores, especially one that explores a geographic area 探险家，考察者
no longer in view 在视野以外，看不见
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The woman didn't go into the house until her daughter drove away and slowly faded out of sight.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  蝴蝶
n. a long strip 长列
n.  蚂蚁
a. shaped like a triangle 三角形的   triangle n. a flat, three-sided geometric figure 三角形
n. a number of warships under one command 舰队
n. a small open boat that one sails or rows 小帆船，划子
vi.  move in an unbalanced way 摇晃，摇摆
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The child's voice wobbled with emotion.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 用大砍刀砍削而成的
n. a pole with a flat blade pulled by hand to row a boat 桨
n. (usu. pl) a shallow place or area in a body of water 浅水域，浅滩
n.  竹（竿）
vt. pierce with a sharp stake or point 刺穿，钉住
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The boy fell out of the window and was impaled on the fence.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. cut, chop 砍，斩
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He had his arm lopped off by an electric saw.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 装饰，装饰品
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. When will they finish the decoration of the bathroom?

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 苍鹭
v. walk slowly and heavily on（在…上）缓慢而沉重地行走
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Don't bother him right now. He's plodding through a mountain of paperwork.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 翠鸟
n. 布谷鸟，杜鹃
vi.  move quickly and noisily; (cause to) make continuous loud noises by hitting hard objects against each other 喧闹地移动；（使）咔嗒咔嗒地响
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She dropped the bucket and it went clattering down the stairs.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. bustle about; give too much attention to small and unimportant matters 忙乱；大惊小怪
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. As soon as they saw the manager the waiters began fussing around the tables.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 船头
vt. shoot; hit with something flat 弹射；拍击
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Catherine responded to the man's attempt by slapping him.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 弹弓
n.  皮带
too far away to be reached, seen or heard 在射程外的，够不到的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We thought that we were out of range of their rifles until the bullets started kicking up the dust in front of us.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  热带雨林
a.  a covering that can be pulled down over a window 窗帘
n. 海岸线
vi. move wildly or violently 猛烈摆动，翻腾
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The swimmers were thrashing about in the water.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 巨滑舌鱼（南美食用大型淡水鱼）
n. 水虎鱼（南美产的一种小鱼）
n. 鳗，鳝鱼
vt. hang or swing loosely 摆动；悬垂
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A kite is dangling from a telephone wire.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. an untidy pile of something 一堆，大量
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He left his books in a heap on the floor.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  愁苦的；渴求的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. a wistful expression

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 修女，尼姑
a.  too bright to be seen easily 耀眼的  dazzle vt.  blind with bright light 使眼花，使目眩
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His second film has been a dazzling success.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. move quickly and silently with ease; fly through the air without power 轻快无声地走；滑翔
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. At the sight of me she glided across the dance floor to greet me.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 藤条
a. (of sounds) very high in pitch 音调高的，尖声的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. a high-pitched debate

NewWords.WordPhrase: pron.  （古）（thou的宾格）= you
vi. move in a crowd 成群地移动，蜂拥
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A dark cloud of bees came swarming out of the hive.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi.  (of a person) jump on one foot; (of a bird or other animals) jump with two or all feet at once（人）单足跳，跳跃；（鸟和其他动物）齐足跳
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The birds hopped about and pecked the earth briskly, looking for seeds and insects.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 僧侣穿戴的头巾（或带头巾的长袍）
n. 屋顶
